Star Wars: Empire at War is a real-time strategy game from Petroglyph and published by LucasArts, the best strategy game in Star Wars franchise. Gold Pack also include the expansion pack Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption in one package.

Star Wars: Empire at War gameplay is more like map conquest called galaxy conquest since this is the Star Wars galaxy, you start on a galactic map, establishes bases on planets like Coruscant, Tatooine or Naboo, build up armies and galactic fleet, then engage in space or ground battles on map in real epic battles. Played this game maybe 80 hours on the old retail DVD and it has not aged a day in my eyes.  Game is a spiritual successor to Rebellion which in turn was a time sink i played in the 90's more than i care to admit. reviewText:
As of June or some other month in 2015, or maybe 2014, whenever GameSpy shut down, this game NO LONGER has multiplayer. In order to play with your buddies you will have to download and install a program such as Evolve or Tunngle, in order to play online over LAN.

Star Wars Empire at War is a strategy game.

Unlike some strategies, Empire at War is very basic. With little micro management, and a small unit cap. This makes it great for those new to the genre, who are looking to get into it.

The gameplay is in real-time. Meaning it is actually fun, unlike turn-based titles. There are two types of battles: space, and land.

In space battles you have a space station, which you can upgrade. Through this station, you build new units and buy upgrades for them, unlocking more units and upgrades as you upgrade the station. You must destroy the enemy's station to win.

The land battles put you on a planet in the Star Wars universe. You have a base with multiple buildings, each one allowing you to buy different units/upgrades. As with the space station, you can upgrade your central command building to unlock more advanced technology. You must destroy the enemy's base to win.

With both battle types, you can change the win conditions. So instead of just having to destroy their base, you have to wipe them out completely, etc.

The Gold Pack comes with both the original Empire at War, and the Forces of Corruption expansion pack. Unfortunately Forces of Corruption has some balance issues, but the game is still extremely fun.

The original game allows you to play as either the Empire or the Rebellion. It has it's own campaign, which is around 5 hours or so in length. But as with most strategy games, the campaign is more of a slow tutorial to prepare you for multiplayer.

Forces of Corruption adds a new campaign, and also allows you to play as the Consortium. Which adds new units, upgrades, abilities, and requires you to change your strategy in certain ways.

The multiplayer still has a very active, but very small, community. If you do plan to get the game, be sure to switch your location to the US in the options, otherwise you will see few, if any, matches.

Empire at War is an excellent RTS, and definitely one to consider getting whether you are a veteran of the genre, or have never played one before.

reviewText:
Star Wars: Empire at War puts you straight into the centre of galactic war in real time strategy fashion. Depicting the struggle of the Rebels, the Empire, and the Zann Consortium. The game is loosely set between the events of Episode III and Episode IV in Star Wars.

Players have three campaigns to choose from. The Rebels campaign that takes them across the galaxy to stop the Empire’s advance and stop their new super weapon. The Empires campaign works closely with Darth Vader himself as he tries to crush the remaining Rebel forces, complete the Death Star construction and prevent the leaked plans getting in front of the Rebel leaders. lastly the Zann Consortium campaign where you seek to spread your corruption across the galaxy and earn vast riches along the way. All campaigns are very well written and while linear, they offer a few side missions to add some extra life to the campaign experience.

In addition to those story driven campaigns, players can also take on the entire galaxy in the galactic conquest mode where players can play as the Rebels, the Empire or the Zann Consortium as they try to achieve particular objectives. There are a number of grand strategy elements present in these modes as you manage funds from the planets under your control and use those funds to improve your troops, research technology and more to get a leg up on the opposing forces. Also you can battle it out in shorter battles in the skirmish mode. Regardless of which you choose to get the Star Wars strategy experience from you’ll find a good mixture of vehicle, infantry and even spacecraft battles to enjoy.

With plenty of Star Wars references and characters littered throughout the game, it’s a strategy experience that will definitely resonate with Star Wars fans more than anyone else. Star Wars fan or not though the strategy experience is worth playing with real time and grand strategy fans both catered for.

reviewText:
Star Wars Empire at War combines a great combination of ground and space combat which not only looks great but also plays well.

The game works around the idea of a galactic map with planets that you control. these create a general map that you have to conquer, each planet can change control to whoever conquers it and has two levels of defence that you can have.
Ground defence allows you to have fight in traditional RTS ways where you have to eliminate the hostile forces to capture the planet  or stop an invasion force.

Space combat allows you to bring large or small ships into combat using RTS gameplay, this creates great combat and gives you the oportunity to play as you want. there can also be a space station and defences that you can build / destroy making space combat vary in each fight.

the game in general is good fun for anyone who likes RTS games with a unique take on the genre. i find that it is enjoyable and the game has its own fan made expansion which completely overhauls the game and changes the empire and rebels to republic and federation. This allows for an entirely new type of gameplay as the new units have far more weapon spots and units which makes your screen light up with turbo lasers.

the expansion however can run a bit slugish if you go insane and spam battledroids as the game tanks and doesnt run too well.

in general i would say if you like RTS conquest games then give this a shot, its pretty cheap now and the free expansion Republic at War allows for a near whole new game.

reviewText:
As RTS games go, this title isn't going to redefine the genre in any way. But that doesn't stop it from being an enjoyable enough game, especially if you're a Star Wars nut. Personally i find the space battles to be the real highlight for me, they're just so much better than ground force battles. I also must admit to having NEVER played as the rebel alliance, i always play as the Empire... purely because their ships and vehicles look so much better! For this reason i'm not sure just how balanced the gameplay is in terms of unit strength or if the number of recruitable units varies to make up for the difference in strength... after all, sure an AT-AT is going to be pretty tough to beat, but i wouldn't fancy the rebels chances if the Empire could recruit as many AT-AT's as the rebels can recruit in soldiers!

Those of you who want to play as the rebels will be at least partially pleased to hear that the AT-AT doesn't appear until VERY late in the campaign. Same applies to the vast Executioner class Star Destroyers, although those ships seem to be lacking in firepower and are little more than enormous target practice sites. The bad news for the rebels though is if the Empire manage to finish constructing the Death Star and retrieve the stolen plans, they've already as good as won. If you're playing as the Empire then consider this good news, especially as you then get to destroy 4 or 5 planets and revel in genuine global destruction.

In terms of graphics and audio, this game is fine and has stood the test of time well. In terms of gameplay it's pretty simple, bringing in little in the way of new features to the RTS genre. So if you're a fan of Star Wars and like the established RTS style of game, you're going to really enjoy this. If you're looking for something new, this will be a very shallow game indeed.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I do believe this is worth buying but I caution you if you are a fan of RTS games that this may not be what you are used to. The modding community has also done wonders with this game and for the Republic at War mod alone is worth buying the game.

The game is split into 2 distinct parts. The galaxy overview where you build bases, move your troops and play in a Risk like format. The second part is the the RTS side of the game where you control your troops directly. This is further split into space combat and ground combat. I'm going to give each a review and then add the sum for my total review.

First with the ground combat it always involves protecting or destroying the buildings. The defending side get's units through deployed troops already built and gets further free troops from buildings designed to construct units. The offensive side I find often is at a disadvantage and it becomes of game of invading with totally overwhelming numbers or playing more tactically with stealth based units. This generally ends up being long winded and downright boring battles in the later parts of the game where the combat is meant to be more fast and furious to keep a game going. For the ground combat I'd give it a 2/5.

Second the space combat. This is where the game really shines and you can recreate some of the great moments from the movies. The Rebels and the Empire both play very differently and it keeps the fights fresh each time. The Imperials go for that ovewhelming numbers and get free Tie Fighters and bombers from the capitol ships. The Rebels why they need to buy Fighters and Bombers are generally more well rounded to deal with threats. Capitol ships on both sides play fairly the same with your standard Rebel Crusiers and Star Destroyers but what makes space combat so unique is that larger ships and space stations have hardpoints to target. To many Tie fighters take out the hangar. Mon Calamari Cruiser flanking around you take out its engines and leave it stranded. This adds a whole new dimension to and RTS that I've never played before and makes it a truly tactical experience. Space combat gets a 5/5.

Finally the Galaxy Overview portion. It's fairly straightforward and just involves moving units, building bases on planets, sabatoging enemy bases and upgrading the tech tree. For players who don't want to play the battles can actually play and entire match from this screen and let the computer simulate the battles for you. It's different, it's cool, it's noting totally special but does offer a new take at strategy games. The Galaxy overview gets a 4/5.

Don't expect much difficulty from the computer. The AI is somewhat dissapointing but fear not. One of the best parts of this game is what the modders have created for it. The Republic at War mod can take the place of the expansion and allows you to play out the Republic vs. Seperatist conflict. The AI in that is tough. I'm at the point where all I play is Republic at War and it offers the challenge that I was looking for from an AI in an RTS. AI gets a 4/5.

So when you add it up the game is a 15/20. That takes into accounts both the vanilla game and the modded game. The modded version is much better and totally free so it's absolutely worth getting. Vanilla version is more for people who want to learn the game or are big Star Wars fans. In all it's not super difficult and definately different from most RTS games on the market. I definately recommend this game!

Star Wars Empire at War is a gem, perfect for those who are looking for a slow but entertaining real time strategy game that takes place in the Star Wars universe.

-Challenging.

-Battle Camera can allow players view battles in a way seen in the movies.
-The game can be replayed a ton due to Galactic Conquest and Skirmish.

-The game can get repetitive without any modifications.
-Without Workshop, modding can become difficult.
-The artificial intelligence is not the best, sure you can be out-smarted by them in your first game but you will learn and there will be no way to lose.
-Ground battles can be annoying, especially when you kill everything but one person is hiding somewhere.

reviewText:
Having logged countless hours in the retail version back when retail was up-to-date, I was eager to play it again and replay an awesome RTS in the SW universe.  Now before the actual review, I would like to warn windows 8 users: MAKE SURE THAT YOU DO NOT BUY THE RETAIL VERSION!!! You will find this game super cheap on Amazon, E-Bay, etc, but they will not run correctly on win8 systems. There is an official patch to fix this, but it doesn't always fix the whole problem. However, you will not need to patch and/or modify the game on steam to work :)

Now for the review:

Yes EaW is old, but it can compete with most current RTS games pretty well. EaW brings cool ideas to the table like space battles, hero units, and a conquest mode in which you have to conquer the galaxy!!! While EaW wasn't the first to do some of those things, they sure did them right. Ok now time for the generic Pros and Cons section:


Pros:
Doesn't feel repetitive
Has a large map variety
Explores a part of the SW timeline from an interesting new perspective
It's in the SW universe!!!
Space Battles
Balancing is ok (Aside from the Rebels and their suprise armadas out of nowhere!)
Zann Consortium adds a fun new play style



Cons
Kinda pricy for an old game
Graphics (Expected from an old game)
Battles should be bigger (There's probably a mod for that)
MP is dead :( (There are programs for running MP on Gamespy dependent games though, look up Evolve or Gameranger)
Rebels are really OP and can do massive suprise invasions



Conclusion:

If you like Star Wars, RTS games, or both, then buy this game. If you are looking for stunning graphics and scripted events every minute, then this game is not for you. A fantastic, well-developed, excellently made strategy game that is incredibly fun to play, and simultaneously challenging to a very customiseable degree.

The rebellion are annoying to fight against, with strong abilities to evade space fights and strike right at the ground, having the most number of heroes and the strongest collection of force users. Their space units aren't too shoddy either

They lack any particular strengths in terms of space or land, but their Droidekas and Canterous Tanks make excellent ground forces, and their Keildabe-class battlecruisers aren't too shoddy.

The Empire is glorious. Pilot the SUPER STAR DESTROYER Executor in climactic (and very one-sided) battles across the galaxy, exploding space stations and planets with the Death Star and being incredibly intimidating and awe-inspiring. The Empire, despite less population space in space, is clearly the winner in any machup, and on ground the formidable arsenal of AT-AT's, Stormtroopers, AT-AA, Sith, and repulsor tanks makes them nigh impossible to remove without heavy losses or superior tactics.

Empire at war is for anyone who has ever wanted to feel the sheer power of commanding thousands of units into space battle against thousands of other units. For the Empire!

reviewText:
There are three Star Wars games that should really set the bar for any that follow them: Star Wars: Jedi Knight III: Jedi Academy, Star Wars: Battlefront II, and the one you are looking at right now, Star Wars: Empire at War.

Essentially a Total War game in the Star Wars universe, albeit with a realtime campaign map as opposed to turn-based, this game offers a deeply enjoyable RTS and Grand Strategy experience, all set in the wonderful world of Star Wars. Play the Empire and crush the rebellion with your lumbering fleets of Star Destroyers and the legendary planet-destroying planetoid, the Death Star. Alternatively, shatter the tyranny of the Empire as a fledgeling Rebel Alliance, utilizing fast and agile ships to run circles around your foe.

Ultimately, of the three gameplay modes, Space Battles are where the game design shines the most, followed closely by the campaign map, both of which overshadow, by a large degree, the lackluster ground battles. But this is not an issue. The Space Battles and Campaign map are so engrossing that you will likely get more fun and replayability out of those two modes alone, than a version of this game where more time were diverted to making better ground battles.

Ultimately, I highly recommend this classic gem of a game to Star Wars and strategy gaming fans alike!

P.S. I have probably over 200 hours in this game on the CD version, which I had since barely a month after its release!

reviewText:
This is an amazing RTS game with three main areas. Ground Strike. Space Conflict. Planetary Management.
Ground Strike is both in the main conquest modes and skirmish. It is where you take your infantry, tanks, scouts, and heavy tanks to try to destroy the enemy base or otherwise win. No battle is the same.
Space Conflict is again main conquest modes and skirmish. You take your fleets against the opposing fleets and there is usually a massive space station for one side or both.
Planetary Management is for the conquest modes and is where you decide what structures are built on each world and which units you build.
This game is incredibly addictive and has many mods for it that take literally seconds to install with ease so even if you have beatne the campaign and Galactic Conquest a dozen times for each side, just put on a mod and try it all again.

reviewText:
Honestly, it doesn't seem like this game came out 5 years ago. This is one of my favorite RTS's of all time, right next to AoE. The dual plane RTS mechanic is what makes this game a great balance between combat and building your empire. I have yet to replay  through the story, but I recall it being really fun and quite long (If you consider the different story lines just one campaign, it is even longer). Also, being able to refine and hone in your ground combat skills in the skirmish mode is very helpful, since you don't have to initiate an extensive galactic conquest match. Since I don't want to have a wall of text, nor feel like making an in depth review, just buy this game. Here is a synopsis of why you should:

+ Star Wars
+ Really great space battles
+ Fun ground battles
+Great sounds and sound track
+ A good learning curve; this game can appeal to casual gamers as well as hardend RTS players. It just depends on how much time you want to put into the game, and if you want a challenge (the CPU opponents can get pretty feisty lol)
+ A plethora of units from the entire Star Wars galaxy
+ The cinematic view is cool
+ Space battles in particular are super fun to just sit back and watch. Something about them lasers...

Really the only con(s) would be
- Price. But the game gives you so much content for a fraction of the cost of a big name companies would charge. That said, I'd suggest getting it on sale if you still have reservations about buying it
- Graphics. The game is 5 years old, what do you expect? Even so, it really isn't that bad maxed out, it actually looks quite good for its age!

All in all, great game. I have yet to find anything bad/wrong about the game. 10/10

EDIT:
I've since played throught the campaign, and its really fun. Not necessarily note worthy story telling, and there isn't much of a plot, but I still found it entertaining to play through. It isn't as long as I recalled, being that it took me ~5hrs and I was purposely taking my time.

reviewText:
Honestly, it doesn't seem like this game came out 5 years ago. This is one of my favorite RTS's of all time, right next to AoE. The dual plane RTS mechanic is what makes this game a great balance between combat and building your empire. I have yet to replay  through the story, but I recall it being really fun and quite long (If you consider the different story lines just one campaign, it is even longer). Also, being able to refine and hone in your ground combat skills in the skirmish mode is very helpful, since you don't have to initiate an extensive galactic conquest match. Since I don't want to have a wall of text, nor feel like making an in depth review, just buy this game. Here is a synopsis of why you should:

+ Star Wars
+ Really great space battles
+ Fun ground battles
+Great sounds and sound track
+ A good learning curve; this game can appeal to casual gamers as well as hardend RTS players. It just depends on how much time you want to put into the game, and if you want a challenge (the CPU opponents can get pretty feisty lol)
+ A plethora of units from the entire Star Wars galaxy
+ The cinematic view is cool
+ Space battles in particular are super fun to just sit back and watch. Something about them lasers...

Really the only con(s) would be
- Price. But the game gives you so much content for a fraction of the cost of a big name companies would charge. That said, I'd suggest getting it on sale if you still have reservations about buying it
- Graphics. The game is 5 years old, what do you expect? Even so, it really isn't that bad maxed out, it actually looks quite good for its age!

All in all, great game. I have yet to find anything bad/wrong about the game. 10/10

EDIT:
I've since played throught the campaign, and its really fun. Not necessarily note worthy story telling, and there isn't much of a plot, but I still found it entertaining to play through. It isn't as long as I recalled, being that it took me ~5hrs and I was purposely taking my time.

Oi, I wanted to love this game I really did.  Ok First things first.  Yes it's a big galaxy strategy game of Star wars, you can build fleets and armies, have land and space battles, build star destroyers etc, it's all there.
BUT: When I'm playing it I'm thinking, for every thing the game does well, there's two things that crop up that make me think, 'rebellion did this better six years earlier'.
1)You get limited 'command points' so that the biggest battle you get is about 5 star destroyers... if you have 20, fine, they come in one at a time as reinforcements.
2) Ships repair automatically, so if you cripple a ship in a hit and fade mission, eg, you play as rebels, fly in blast a big star destroyer, fly out then your main fleet comes in just after, literally 1 second can transpire, which represents maybe 1/12 of a galactic day, and that ship will be completely fixed.  So anything you don't destroy is immediately repaired.  That seems like basic logic has gone WAY out the window.
3) You can not sabotage anything, you can only steal technology as the rebels, so usig spec forces or whatever doesn't come into it all.
4) Ground battles are  alittle repetitive, and if for eg, you take over a planet, you can't build defences on the ground level until a battle starts... WHAT THE HELL! So eg you can build BIG things like Ion cannons or shields for the planet, but little 'build pads' for local defences to help you shoot down AT-AT's or whatever can't be built until an invading army arrives... what was my army doing for the six months I held that planet, just standing there? Then they go.. 'oh right, the enemy is landing, maybe we shouldn't have been just giving each other piggy back rides this whole time...'

These might sound niggly as problems, and  they are, but they and a few more I wont mention REALLy pile up to hold the game back from being great.

reviewText:
This particular ditty was released back in 2006 and at the time, I couldn’t have been more excited.  A game like this was a long time coming, as the last title to have a similar theme (“Star Wars: Rebellion”) was released back in 1998.  I won’t bother reviewing a game that is well over five years old, but I will say that it was an incredible feat and achievement.



Essentially, the player will control either the Rebels or the Imperials and attempt to wipe the other out.  Galactic Conquest mode will let you play a game similar to what you may have experienced in “Star Wars: Rebellion”.  You’ll attempt to grow your empire by capturing planets, which in turn gives you more money in which to expand further and build fleets.  Unlike “Rebellion”, you’ll be in complete control of both space and land battles, though you can automate them if you wish.  Skirmish modes are available for those who just want a quick fix, though it doesn’t do Galactic Conquest justice.



An expansion was released later that year (“Forces of Corruption”) that adds a third faction.  This faction resembles a pirate faction that acts very differently during Galactic Conquest mode. I honestly wasn’t very fond of this new faction, as spreading corruption around for the sake of earning credits was tedious and repetitive.  The expansion also forced all three to be played in Galactic Conquest mode, rather than allowing you to pick and choose which factions would be present.  Luckily, Steam lets me load the core game and not the expansion when I want to eliminate this faction.



Overall, still a great game after all these years.

As far as timeline is concerned it's more along the lines of A New Hope than any other point.  Anyway, what's nice about this game is that there's space combat and ground combat, and the campaigns dive into both.  You build an army, send it to a planet, space combat if necessary, then land on the planet for a ground assault.  Simple, effective, and fun.
There's Galactic Conquest which follows the same type of gameplay as the main campaign but a more do at your own pace and strategy.  This is where balance imo becomes more lopsided.  After playing a few rounds with either side, I've come to this conclusion.  The Rebels ARE FAR stronger than the Empire in terms of Navy and Army.  Empire have certain units that are most definitely stronger, IE Star Destroyers and AT-AT's, but as a unit the Rebels just kick so much ♥♥♥, even the heroes are more than a match for Empire heroes.  Each side also has special abilities, Empire can build a deathstar and instant blow up planets and systems, while the Rebels can sneak attack a planet they deem weak enough to liberate under the Empire's noses.
Every planet is different however, some side with Rebels making it harder to win for Empire and vice versa.  Some can't have speeders on the planet, so yes, strategy abounds in this game.

Then there's the skirmish mode, it's so weird.  You don't have to build any main buildings (like a barrecks), they're already prebuilt, you just upgrade your soldiers, build mines/turrets, summon soldiers, and that's it, but this is where my biggest gripe comes in.

The enemy players regardless of difficulty, WILL BUM RUSH YOU!  They will send every available soldier they have straight to your base, so if you don't build anti-infantry turrets right away, you're going to have a bad time, seriously.  What's more annoying is that even if you build turrents, they will try to run straight past them straight for a target at your base.  The ai logic is ♥♥♥♥ poor to the max.  It's also randomized so sometimes games will be harder than others, again regardless of difficulty.  All in all, the game has held up for quite a while as it came out almost 10 years ago, but the poor ai logic can sometimes just kill the game.  I give it a solid 8/10, great game, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ai

reviewText:
RTS is my favourite genre though I mainly like base building RTS games like Age of Empires 2 and Red Alert 2.
I never really liked the games where you just have some units and you will have to do everything with that.

However, one day I won a steam key for this game and since I like Petroglyph Games and saw the first (oldest) 3 Star Wars movies I was pretty excited.

Since I mostly played base building games and didn't focus much on micro management I had to take some time to get into this game. At first I didn't fully understand why this game was received so well beside it's nice (Star Wars) atmosphere. However when I played some more and got further into the campaign I began to understand that also the gameplay was quite fun :).

Positive:
- The Star Wars part of the game is VERY well done. The models look great, the landscapes, flora, fauna and weather are nicely done, the sound effects and music are good and the Star Wars characters are also well done. If you are a Star Wars fan, that part of the game won't disappoint you. The atmosphere of the game is just really nice.
- Apart from the Star Wars part the graphics and design is well done. The user interface looks nice and is easy to use, the graphics look good, the models are pretty detailed, the terrain is detailed, effects are also nice.
- The gameplay is quite nice. You have a galaxy  map on which you can manage your planets. You can build structures on planets, trains/produce units if you have the necessary structures, research/steal tech, spy etc. There are units for on land and units for in space. All units can freely travel to planets in real time (though the galaxy map can be paused). Some planets are connected via some sort of travel lane which makes travelling between those planets faster which may prove benificial when controlling the planets. some planets have room for more building than others and planets may have bonuses if you control them. You can capture planets by destroying all ground buildings and units of the opponent controlling the planet. Before you can land your ground units on a planet you need to clear the space units around the planet (in a space battle) along with the space station and perhaps defences though none of these thing may be present (which makes it more easy :)).
On land battles you need to destroy the enemy base (if there is one, can be build on the galaxy map) and all enemy units. The map layouts are quite nice. There are hardpoints spread around the map which can be captured and then used to put turrets on. There are infantry only zones, native threats (or allies) and wheather effects. If you got bombers in orbit of the planet you can call in bombing runs.

Negative:
- Gameplay may become somewhat monotone. Though this may also just be me, because I get that more often.

Conclusion:
If you like Star Wars and RTS games that focus more on tactics then this is probably a very nice game for you. If you mostly like basebuilding RTS games then you should be somewhat more carefull. I think this is a pretty good game and would rate it somewhere around 80/100, but it just isn't for everybody.

reviewText:
Ignore how many hours I have logged on steam, I had this game on disc before and easily have hundreds, possibly a thousand hours unlogged on it.

Onto the review:
NOTE:I have only played Star Wars: Empire at War, not the Forces of Corruption expansion that also came with the Steam version, thus that makes this review for the core game itself, not the FoC expansion!

GameplayThe game itself is an RTS. Rebellion vs Empire in the Star Wars universe that features a galactic map system (Something people might be familiar with in the old Star Wars Battlefront games). However EAW features both land and space battles in a two-step invasion system to conquer a planet. The ultimate goal is to take control over the entire galaxy, but to achieve it smaller, and much more tedious and annoying goals must be finished. The online multiplayer last time I checked no longer functions due to gamespy shutting down their multiplayer servers (RIP). But back when it was online there were a few gamemodes, none I really played. It had a fairly sizable modding community which provided custom maps, Which I am not sure you can get anymore as they were hosted on filefront. Not to say this game is boring, but just throwing out there that there are custom maps for this game you could find.

Standard MapsEvery planet (Excluding one, the astroid fields.) has it's own space and ground map, which will lead to hours of gameplay alone as you battle through each of them for either faction. But be aware a lot of them have native species which will either side with you, your enemy, or themselves. There are build pads scattered across the maps in key locations and choke points where you can build turrets (AA, AT, and AI), radar scanners (Sensor Nodes), or a medical station/vehicle repair station.

Misc.The graphics on thisgame show their date. The game itself is pretty old. But like I stated before, there are mods for that. Just use google and you can probably still find them.
This game has very few custom songs, maybe none at all from what I know. All the music I have heard in this game is recycled from the official movie's soundtracks.
I would especially recommend this game for newer players getting into the RTS genre as it is a very forgiving game on the easier difficulties. RTS veterans would still have a bit of a problem playing on the hardest difficulty as I have found the AI player does not really have many restrictions on it, meaning it will start producing units from multiple locations at the same time and have dozens of fleets moving at the same time, leaving the player at a severe disadvantage.

reviewText:
/!\CAUTION/!\ I have a lot of nostalgia towards this game. I don't know if Nostalgia is blinding my judgement or not!

Star Wars: Empire at War is a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game set in the Star Wars universe. It got an expansion pack which expands the game a lot.

Good things:
-The main game has 2 campaigns, 2 factions, and a lot of planet to play with. Meaning a lot of different ways to win/lose.
-Battles on Foot AND in space. And in the WHOLE FREAKING GALAXY.
-Newcomer friendly. This game got me into strategy, and seeing as how I f*cking love this genre, it's a VERY good thing.
-It's about the Galactic Civil War. Meaning you get to play as DARTH VADER.
-The expansion packs adds a 3rd campagin, faction, and a dozen of planets.
-With the expansion pack, you get to chose your base's layout. This may not seem like a huge thing, but it can be important depending on your playstyle.
-You get to use THE DEATH STAR(s).
-The 3rd Faction has Destroyer Droids. Nuff' said.

Bad things:
-This game's graphics aged REALLY badly.
-It's set in the Galactic Civil War. Meaning you don't get to play as CRISTOPHER LEE (R.I.P.).
-Boba Fett is Empire only. Even with the 3rd Faction.
-The Death Star may make your game crash. (That's not a good thing in case you're wondering)
-If you don't have the Expansion Pack, Luke is Space only. And with the Expansion Pack, he's on foot only.
-The main game has cinematics in case you lose/win. The Expansion Pack doesn't. Because F*ck you.

It is a fantastic game, I would highly recommend it. Especially to any Star Wars fans out there.

However the game has one flaw on steam, the launching of the expansion (that steam thinks is a DLC) doesn't work properly. Therefore you must right click the Star Wars: Empire at War Gold pack, open properties, set launch options and type in the following: swfoc MODPATH=Mods\n
When you now click launch FoC (Forces of Corruption), it will now correctly launch Foc instead of Eaw (The basic game, Empire at War).
I hope this will help new players of the game that encounter this problem. I also wish you a fun time with the title, and don't forget to check out the mods. There are several set in the era after the original trilogy (Thrawn's Revenge, Awakening of the Rebellion) and quite a few set in The Clone Wars era (The Clone Wars, Republic At War).

Have fun, and may the force be with you.

reviewText:
Sluggish controls, tactical map unit caps, and a real time macrostrategic map of the galaxy make this a pain. Yes, there's a pause button on the galactic map, but you can't do anything while paused like move fleets or build units. It only works on the tactical map. Also, some of the scenario maps seem glitched on tech levels. If you go to advanced settings and reduce the starting tech level while playing on hard, then you start with reduced technology but the computer starts with regular technology. Having X Wings, Y Wings, and basic frigates doesn't really match top of the line Imperial Star Destroyers.

There's also no hold position command. You can tell units to stop, but it's very easy to lure or get lured, especially when units won't respond instantly after being lured. This creates a very annoying situation where rocket infantry wreck light tanks, anti-infantry vehicles wreck light infantry, and aircraft become pointless (although aircraft dominate easily until AA weapons are around). In space, it means fighters and bombers won't withdraw from cruisers, and larger ships that are slightly misoriented beacuse they advanced two inches too far take forever to turn around.

The game really isn't that bad, but it's like they choked it for no good reason and ruined the experience. If the units were responsive, tactical map unit caps didn't exist, the galactic map was turn based instead of real time, and the pause button let you issue orders while paused, then this would be an easy thumbs up. I have no idea why they ruined their own game with arbitrary restrictions.

reviewText:
Empire at War is probably the Star Wars' most serious foray into the strategy genre, and I hate to say it's mixed at best. While the battlescapes make for some really impressive visuals, the game falls flat on its face on the tactical map.

It's one of the worst I've ever seen in a strategy game. It's real time with a pause, which wouldn't be an issue execpt the game refuses to let you make any meaningful orders while paused. It will only be an hour or so before you started getting bombarded with battle prompts (which you can autoresolve) back-to-back, and it just becomes completely unmanagable as your attention is constantly divided. It seriously plays like a turn-based system that was retooled to realtime at the very last second, and its shows. I cannot understate how frustrating it is to deal with.

And while the battlescape is fun to play on, it also has issues. Pathfinding for you or the AI is atrocious, and you'll often have to bear ships taking a full minute to turn around when they could have just moved forward. On top of some pretty awful unit balance, battles are always completely lopsided and predictable.

Do not get this on anything but the cheapest of sales. The cool battles might draw you in, but the game turns into a slog very, very quickly.

reviewText:
Horribly unbalanced and dated game.

While the graphics may look appealing, even today, the gameplay is an entirely different story. Both on land and space battles, there are units and certain aspects of different factions that you can exploit to garantee a win.
If you decide to play a conquest game, beware when fighting against the Empire. If they are able to build a death star, it can quickly decimate the areas you control. When defending against it in space, you will have a couple of minutes to try and destroy every last space craft the enemy has, before they'll be able to use the death star to instantly destory your space station or planet, forcing you to lose the battle.
The Consortium is just as bad. While they have most of the cool and fun to use units, all of their units are designed to ignore your units shields, auto kill any fighters you have, etc. while they have individually shielded structures, and gain bonuses to what really matters (space station wise), hard points.
Most larger ships and space stations have things called 'hard points', such as turbo lasers, ion canons, proton torpedos, engines, and shields. Once destroyed, they can not be recovered. While the Empire and Rebels usually can increase their shield strength or firepower, the Consortium increases the armor on their space stations hardpoints. Why this is so important is because each faction has at least one or two units that can bypass shields, usually missile ships or bombers, so shields aren't entirely important to bolster. Being able to better defend your hard points is a little more effective.
As for on the ground, both the empire and rebellion have a unit that can fly, a special, unique kind of unit that ignores most rules of combat. Bolstering incredibly high mobility and decent firepower, they can skip the ground combat and go right for the enemies base. With a large enough force, most units wouldn't be able to shoot them down, while you quickly wittle away at their forces and structures. Seriously, they are just that powerful.
This doesn't mean I hate the concept of this game. Rather, I hate how little thought and care was put into the game. It had the potential to be so much better, and I would love to see someone try and remake the game.
I strongly recommend not buying the game for more than $6.

I loved Galactic Battlegrounds and have enjoyed many others in the same genre, like C&C, AOE, etc.

I feed stupid for saying it, but this was too difficult for me.  The first bit of the tutorial was a breeze, but as soon as the second one started, I was lost.  Drag this there.  Zoom in.  Click that.  I followed what I was told to do, but didn't have much comprehension as to why.  There was too much information given to me in that second tutorial and I was unable to absorb it in order to use that knowledge in-game.

I skipped the rest of the tutorials and started a campaign (on easy) to see how much the information on the second tutorial impinged on the game.  On the second part of the campaign, I was presented with the world map - right there, I was lost.  I dragged R2-D2 onto the planet I was meant to, and did the same for a couple of troops, but when I zoomed in to that planet, it said the battle was starting so onto the ground I went.  Moved right a little while and found a laser turret, quickly followed by more troops than I had.  Didn't last long before I was wiped out.  The commentary said to call for reinforcements but I'd no idea how to do that.

Should I have dragged more troops on before getting to the planet?  I understand that Empire at War can't just be more of the same that was presented in Galactic Battlegrounds, but this was too much of a departure/advancement for me.  I'd far rather be put on the planet and have to build my base before encountering the turret and troops - I could then have built more if needs be.

Given I'm fine with other similar games, I blame the tutorial.  If it was anything like the one in C&C Red Alert 3, it could impart as much new information as it needed to without the user feeling lost.

I understand I'm in the minority here given 93% of users recommend this - perhaps if I sat with one of them and have them walk me though the basics, I'd have a better chance of enjoying this title, but as it is, I'm sadly deleting it in frustration.

reviewText:
The expansion pack to this game, Forces of Corruption has containd a game breaking bug since it was initially released; to this date it has not been fixed.  The issues is noticed during the main campaign of the FoC; where, if a player corrupts a planet that one of the main characters is suppose to do a campaign mission on, then there is a chance that the character will become stuck on that planet, invisible.  The player will have no way to interact with the character or start the mission.  How you will notice, is that the character will suddenly vanish off of the map after completing the corruption mission.  No matter where you look, it won't be visible.  If you click on it's icon in the upper corner, it will direct you to the planet where the character was suppose to do the mission.  The reason is, because that character is stuck on the planet; just invisible.  This breaks the game.  The only thing you can do is return to an older save and avoid using corruption when you last did it.

The fact that such an aggrivating bug exists in a released product, is enough to earn it a poor rating.

Edit: I deleted some comments due to fallacies.  Just because you never experience a problem with a product; doesn't mean no problems exist.  You can go to the Star Wars wikipage for FoC and see the campaign bug mentioned on the page.  Granted it says that it was patched; but, obviously it wasn't done so effectively if it still persists for players.  There is literally a recent steam community discussion you can look up, where someone is describing the exact issue and multiple other members are trying to help them trouble shoot the issue.  The final concensus was: you guessed it, restart the campaign.

reviewText:
On Steam it says I've barely played this game, but I played a TON of it when it first came out and didn't have it on Steam. Anyways, it's an old game, and I HATE to say it, but it has not aged well. At all. In fact, if I ever play it again, it will be entirely for nostalgia's sake, unfortunately. The problem is the balance, especially in land battles.

The way everything is set up just feels weird. It feels like vehicles can die too easily, the Empire infantry weirdly stack up into box formations that just doesn't really fit with the Star Wars atmosphere, and the rocket artillery on the Rebel's side is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥LY overpowered, to the point where they can almost take out your entire military force at the beginning of a match (yet when you use them, they don't feel nearly as powerful). It's just kind of a weird game, and yes, the space battles are cool, but they have also aged to the point where unfortunately, it's just not worth it anymore. The meta game  (galactic conquest or whatever it's called) is also weird. A lot of time there are strangely fast time limits to win the game, which annoys me because it gives little time to really develop a nice army and tech that can really do damage. And since it's all in real time, it sometimes devolves into a game of tag, where each side has their core planets, and then all the outlying planets are taken by one side, then taken by another, and so on and so forth, and this is due to the unit cap, which restricts you from truly building a large enough force to take over the empire. There's so many connections to all of the planets that it's not easy to actually form a stronghold, and while there is strategy in that, the game isn't quite good enough to compell you to want to develop the skills to master that strategy. I don't think I ever finished a single galactic conquest map. I ended up just reverting to multiplayer (which I can only assume is dead now).

If you played the game before, and just want nostalgia to kick in, maybe pick it up on a sale, but if you've never played it before, I'd say move on to better RTS games.

reviewText:
The first of the Star Wars titles to enter the grand strategy genre, Empire at War was highly anticipated but failed to meet expectations. Major flaws plague every aspect of the game. The developer made the poor decision to make the strategy map run in real-time rather than in a turn-based fashion, resulting in the need for constant pauses and frantic clicking; land battles are campy and boring; and space battles leave no room for tactics, as the bigger fleet nearly always wins by default.

This game was created with an obvious degree of laziness, and the result is a frustrating experience. One can only assume that this arose from complacency on the part of the developer; perhaps it was believed that the Star Wars factor would compensate for the game's obvious shortcomings. If so, the developer was very incorrect.

Don't buy this game.

reviewText:
What a classic!

Had this on disc for years but time to its toll and both the expanision and base discs got damaged to the point of not being read by any drive I put them in.

After seeing this in the sale, I jumped at the chance and instantly bought it.

Empire at War is a great pick-up and go game. It's gameplay is fast enough to not get boring quickly but it still maintains the challenge and pace of a true startegy game. If you have a beefy system, I'd recommend modding the game to allow for (virtually) unlimited population caps, especially in space battles. Nothing more fun than playing with friends and having a massive battles spanning across the entire map.

Don't worry if your system isn't powerful either, my laptop (AMD E1 @ 1.35GHz) can handle pretty large battles with not a huge loss in framerate. Plus it runs it with max details and AA too so I can't complain too much.

As I'm only a user of LAN multiplayer, I cannot comment on the Online support but I believe that programs such as gameranger may help get you playing over the internet.

All in all. Do I recommend this game? Yes and no, while I find it fantastic myself, it's not going to be a showstopper for everyone. If you like Star Wars but are still unsure, wait until a sale and give it a go :)

reviewText:
This game is truly a treat to strategy gamers.

I would call myself a strategy fanatic since mostly the only games I ever play are strategy, and I will easily recommend this as being one of my top five. After the Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds installments, it seemed pretty hard to be able to follow up another decent strategy without making it too modernised and missing out key elements that make true strategy games, especially a Star Wars one also.

But I can truly say they pulled it off with this game. This game is a crystal to the RTS genre and provides players with the ability to be able to Strategically take over the Galaxy, as three different factions fight for power - you have to use all assets at your disposal to assert your faction above others. This power can be asserted by RTS space battles, in which huge fleets massacre eachother, or in RTS ground battles, where every unit has a weakness and strength, meaning that combat must be played strategically.

I recommend this game to anyone looking in the RTS genre, as even for the 20+ hours i've played it, it is a gem to the RTS genre.
